The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Alfred and Dr. Bert. Dr. Alfred's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Bert studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The two are having a casual academic conversation about the function of the higher-order-cortex.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. Alfred: 'What do you think is the primary purpose of the association areas in the mouse cortex?'
Dr. Bert:'What do you mean by primary purpose?'
Dr. Alfred:'When you think about everything in the mouse cortex. What do you think the primary purpose of it is?'

Dr. Bert:'I am trying to answer your question. What I want to know is what you want me to say. Now, if you want me to tell you that, I will say that the primary purpose of that area... in a lot of cases, it seems as though a single thing comes to mind.'
Dr. Alfred:'Now, here is another question. If you, or should I ask what you find the primary purpose of those cortical areas which form part of the associational areas is?'

Dr. Alfred:[Laughing] So, I can't ask you these interesting-looking questions without your laughing, can I? Okay. Okay. Okay. Now, I am going to ask you a, I am going ask you a, no, I am, I am going...'
Dr. Bert:[Laughing] No... no... no...'
Dr. Bert: 'No, you should. You should.'
Dr. Alfred:'Okay. So, your question is... are, are you going to ask me the same question twice? Okay.'
Dr. Alfred:'No, you... you, you, you are. No. Okay. Okay, I am going, I am going.'
Dr. Alfred:'Okay, I am going, and you are...'
Dr. Bert:'No, no. No, no, no, no.'

Dr. Alfred:'Okay. Okay. Okay, well, I am doing just exactly what you are trying to do now. To tell me that the primary purpose, and it seems to be that, is to compute associational information. Now, is that...?'
Dr. Bert:'Yeah. This, right. And that's a fair argument.'
Dr. Alfred:'Yeah. But, well, the brain computes something different in other situations. For instance, when you are driving on the highway, or doing some...?'
Dr, Bert:'Yeah-yeah...'
Dr. Alfred:'Well, yeah, well, yes. So, then, in those kind of...?'

Dr. Alfred:[Laughing, clapping his hand] Because I have just one question. How many of your readers, and, I have read your book, and, and I thought it was a great book. I think it has really solved a very important problem. We have, we have the term 'higher order cortex', which refers essentially to our old, or, or, or it's our old 'precortex;' which is all the, the, the part of the brain that was, the, before the...'

Dr. Bert:'For me, it also seems like the primary purpose of a single thing, which is the primary purpose. And so, I guess I don't see a difference. In any case, I found that the primary purpose seems to be a thing. And if you had asked me 20 years ago, I would have thought that that was the primary purpose, but I am thinking differently now. Now, it is different. It is a process, it is a trajectory. So, if you give me a few minutes, I can remember back to the time when I took the first brain class, and we learned that the hippocampal region is what controls memory, it makes me remember, but that, I don't think is the same as what you are talking about.'

Dr. Alfred:'But what is it like to be the one looking at the problem, at the time when you were thinking about them, when your colleagues thought about, and so you had different ideas about them, which I see now after 20 years. How do you feel about it?'

Dr. Bert:'It is kind of a funny feeling. Very difficult to describe. There may be different words and different metaphors that can be used to explain it, but it is a funny feeling. Because it was so different back then. This is what you asked about, it is this question that I have been struggling with for the past... a long time, actually, since even before I became a scientist. So as a, as a teenager, I wrote a paper that was a, which, I was a naive teenager, and I wrote a paper in 1959 about how brain rhythms are made. And, in fact, the original title of the paper, the original title you wrote, was "The Rhythms of the Brain".'
Dr. Alfred:'Well, it looks like, now I have to give you that paper, because you are a student at this university, and you also worked at this university.'

Dr. Bert: 'No. No. No. Of course, I have, I have read it for years. I have, I, I, it, I am just, I, I... I just read it recently, and, and, and it was a very... very interesting paper, but I, I, I agree with what you were saying. I, I... It did seem that way back in that day.'

Dr. Bert:'So you want the answer from the perspective of the, what do you think is a, what is the primary, who is listening here? My, you, I, or what or who can say, is the question you ask. Now, here is a different way of asking the question. And it would be what is the primary output of the associational area (AFA) of the cortex, which forms, by and large, in the dorsocaudal medial entorhinal cortex, and which is known as the subiculum of the hippocampus, and what is its output, in other words, what is, what is its primary output to, who are we talking, for example, just the subiculum, the associational area and the primary output...'
Dr. Bert:'So, the brain has a mind. What's its job?'
Dr. Bert: 'That's what we're talking about now at any rate. I mean, what do you mean by "brain has a mind"?'
Dr. Alfred:'Do you mean, a kind of memory?'
Dr. Bert: 'Yeah, but in fact, many of them, they are really hard to classify, right?'
Dr. Alfred:'What do you mean by "really hard"?'
Dr. Bert:\'Well,  "Hard" means "hard" in mathematics, and it means the same thing as the adjective  "really,"  or perhaps more precisely  "really hard to classify.'
Dr. Alfred: 'Is the question what function does higher order cortex have or not have?'
Dr. Alfred:'Yeah.'
Dr. Bert:'.. . .  I was just taking a stroll through the mind.... Do you go through all of the association cortices, or what?'
Dr. Bert:'There are multiple things that you can think about in the cortex?'
Dr. Bert: 'Okay. So it's a very complex structure. Okay. Okay.'
Dr. Alfred:"What would you say is the largest organization of the mouse cortex?'
Dr. Bert:(In a manner of speaking.'
Dr. Alfred:(In a manner)..what do you mean? In an analytical scientific manner, what would you say is there largest organization that is the most prominent, the most important?'
Dr. Bert:"Okay. Now how would you define for a non-neuron, for a non-cortical, non-associational area in the cortex as the critical structure that makes the mouse cortex function as a whole?'
Dr. Bert:-    So, it's a large structure in the cortex.'
Dr. Alfred:'But not a large structure in regard to either size of the brain or the number of cells, because it's a relatively small area.'
Dr. Alfred:-   And how many cells does it contain?'
Dr. Bert:'The largest organization of the cortex is the neocortex is the primary visual region.'
Dr. Bert:'I mean, maybe-maybe it sounds a little bit arrogant, but from the outside point of view there are so many of them, right. What do you suggest I do?'
Dr. Bert:''And if you think about the brain without areas. Then what would it be useful for?'

Dr. Alfred:'So you think that in an area you don't have an idea about what the primary purpose is, but if you think about an area that has an idea about, and therefore an idea about what it is useful for, then a piece of work starts to make sense, perhaps?'

Dr. Alfred:'When I try to form a sentence now, I can't think of the exact order of words or the relationships among them. Yet it's clear what the primary purpose of those regions is. But when I actually write in a novel or a paper, the whole thing just falls apart in the first five or six pages. So the real issue is how to generate an order that is internally consistent within a given structure, and we know what the primary goal is.'
Dr. Bert: Okay.'
Dr. Alfred:'I mean, how would you get from your local circuit to a global circuit? What kind of a path would you take?'

Dr. Bert:'Well, it's very straightforward to take an axon cable, but that would leave the cortex empty. But we know, oh, how is it possible to have a system that has a large number of neurons in this small brain, and yet has so many, or at least the same amount of connections we have now? And then we can do something. So that's what I think you have to work out, is as it should work out.'

Dr. Alfred:'As it works out is not just what you know or what you think that's happened, because it's a combination of the two. Do you see? The real goal is to have it so far as you can work it out. In that respect, it's more, if we would say, "how would you solve a problem", or "why is a system of neurons" like an algorithm for solving a problem? But that's not really what we're asking, right? It's how we'd solve it. And this is where the brain is not so smart. It uses a combination of knowledge and computation to do something, but it works very hard. It has a great many algorithms and just as many, many, many other computations, but you can't separate the work of algorithms from, say, working memory, or something.'
Dr. Alfred:'Well, you know, I mean, what do you think the primary purpose of this layer is? Is it to help with the primary purpose?'
Dr. Bert: 'No, what do you do with the parts?'
Dr. Alfred:(laughs) 'Oh, not really.'

Dr. Bert:'No, but that's how we work. We work with the parts. We don't just say, oh, let's say that there's a bunch of neurons and we've got two of them; and we'll ask the parts how do the parts communicate with each other.' Now, you're the parts; how in heaven did you get together? Is it a matter of space and time and other things, or is there some inherent difference between the things at the level of single neurons? Because in the brain there's nothing special about single neurons' properties, not in the sense of some primitives, perhaps, but not in the sense that each cell is its own atom, an individuated single entity. And it seems more likely that the only way to understand how two things come together from the point of view of single neurons is when two neurons are placed next to each other and we ask these two things how do they come together?'

Dr. Alfred:'Oh, very interestingly. You know, I mean what do you think, if all these neurons which are in this layer, are put together in a nice place and we say, let's say there're 20 of them, are there 20 cells with different functions in your brain or would you say that the same neuron would have the same function or similar functions, and that these 20 neurons could come together at all times. And there wouldn't be any space between them.' Now when you look at, say, a layer just above us, that layer which we call the supragranular cortex, the layer which surrounds the primary sensory areas on the left and right, or the right, or the left, I think the average thickness of these cortical plates is, say, approximately 80, which is about 2 millimeters thick.'
Dr. Bert:'Right.'

Dr. Alfred: 'Okay, so if we're looking at the same size brain, which is 10 centimenter long, would there be 20 cells, or maybe one cell, or perhaps only one and even a single one, but the volume would be pretty much the same. And that's because, you know, the volume of the, or at least of the cell bodies and all synaptic processes which surround the cell bodies would be similar in the different areas, right?'

Dr. Bert:'Mm, you know, now that's, it's, you know, this is, it's, it's not that thick; we don't even have to think about these 2 millimeters, because in every book that covers this topic say from single neurons to network mechanisms, they mention the 2 millimeters. So, you know, what should I do, and you, and I, we'll ask a few neurons what do you think and then we'll ask 20 more neurons and I'll get a statistical report on the results, of course, that would be very difficult to do. I mean, of course it would be very difficult because, how should we do the sampling, how many neurons are enough?'
Dr. Alfred: 'Well, in this case, I think we might say three to five. So three to five neuron of a population, the neurons should have been in a nice big place.'

Dr. Alfred:'It sounds as though you're talking about how something comes together from the point where these two neurons - so that these two neurons make a group. Now, for me, the brain is a collection of neurons, and I don't know how it can function or how it can represent something different from the collective behavior of a large number of neurons. I think my preference is the other one, is to look at the collective behavior of neurons and see whether it has primitives and how we can understand these primitives and say, well is it a matter of this, or a matter of that, or it's the combination of these things? But I just don't see it like this.'
Dr. Bert:(laughs) 'Yeah, you're wrong.'
Dr. Alfred: 'I agree, but I'm not wrong or right; we're just different ways of thinking about it.'

Dr. Bert:'Well, let's put it this way. How long is the longest path through the woods? In the sense that we're looking out from the single neuron, which is quite similar to a tree, and we're considering how many synapses are needed to get there from here, because we can start somewhere and end somewhere; but in reality is there an optimal, shortest path through the brain of all possible shortest paths? What I'm suggesting is that the short paths through the brain are often found by following local topographic connections, local connectivity, local dynamics. Now when we use this way of looking at things, we quickly see that it is a case where the path that we're asking to take, to represent the world as a combination of the primitives that we already have, is not quite as efficient as other path that comes back out again and again.'

Dr. Alfred:'Well, I'm not going to argue with you there, but I can't help you because your hypothesis that these circuits don't work according to the rules of physics or anything else, how would an experimenter go about putting these two neurons next to each other in the brain? Because if you could, then in principle you could actually try, then you could maybe see how this path works out, and then you can say, I've got a candidate for the shortest path through the cortex. So where should we start at in order to learn about the shortest path through these two neurons' connection? Where would you suggest to go in order to learn what is the shortest path through two neurons in the cortex?'

Dr. Alfred:'So what is the primary purpose of the two-Dimensional (2-D) grid? Is it to move and track and manipulate our visual and other sensory surroundings or is it to do something else? And the answer is, when we make these measurements, we look at single cells in animals for instance, and say, whoa, whoa, all of a sudden we make a line of sight. Of course we are shocked because people have thought of grid cells as a fundamental element of spatial navigation. And suddenly we realize that it's not an elementary thing any more that grid cells are something special, that there's a special cell type, a simple cell type, and the other cell types represent different things in this environment. Now, there are many things that come together when you think about the 2-D grid in a different way.'
Dr. Alfred:'I was just asking you for your interpretation, your summary, of how it fits together, as a group, how it fits together as a whole.'

Dr. Bert: 'I don't really know what that implies, but it is, to begin with, obviously, it is important because they are used in many different functions. One of them, of course, is memory, but so what? Another one is spatial navigation, but then what? And then something totally new appeared, which may be even much more important as far as we can tell for years now, but, of course, it came all of a sudden in a moment: the idea of the higher order cortex in the behaving mammalian animal, and then, of course, all of a sudden, so what do you think is its primary purpose?'

Dr. Alfred:'Well, as far as we're just starting now to work seriously on this, this is, of course, much too premature to make a decision. But, then, what we're asking is a very large question here, and there are many people who work in this area, like, of course, you would like to answer it. I mean, it is probably the most important question there is, because you're talking about, it is a very large, very important question, which is what are the principles that we, I mean a group of, a people, a community, should go for, or should aim for, or should pursue, when we, we're considering the functioning of a cortical system and how, how, how does it function as a whole, and how do the parts function as a whole. It is a very fundamental question.'
Dr. Alfred:'I mean, the first question is: what is it the animal does?'
Dr. Bert:'Yes.'
Dr. Alfred:"...'

Dr. Bert:"Yes. Well, not to put too much pressure on the question, but I don't know of anyone in the world who has any doubt that this is the fundamental question, as far as one can remember, as far back as any intro-to-brain course I have had.'

Dr. Alfred:'A specific, a goal-directed activity. Just give me [some sort of example]. And then think. I think you come up with something that will be the primary source of activity in these associational areas.'
Dr. Bert: 'Say for example a particular cell assembly.  What would be the primary goal that you would like to assign to that cell assembly?'

Dr. Alfred:'First let me ask you what would be the primary source? In addition to associational areas, I mean, because many times I am interested in other areas as well. And then you give me one or two. And then you say where would you like to assign it.'
Dr. Bert:'No idea.'
Dr. Bert: 'No idea?'
Dr. Alfred:: 'Right.'
Dr. Bert:'Yes, well, when you say association areas you actually mean a different name which is...'
Dr. Bert:-...which is what I call the visual cortex, which we know...'
Dr. Alfred:-Yeah, right, but this is the higher-order?'
Dr. Alfred:'In other words, in the macaque cortex, that area in which the first order of representation is in the primary visual cortex and higher order representation has no place in?'
Dr. Bert:'Not in that area, that is, no place as far as we can see.'
Dr. Alfred:"So this is not...what...does higher-order mean in the sense of being higher than primary cortex..'

Dr. Bert: 'No, that's the area....that is, it's called higher order because that part is higher than primary in the sense of higher order or higher levels of organization, and the higher you go in the hierarchy or structure, the higher order the cortex. And in our brains, this is the most important level of organization in the order of things.'
Dr. Alfred:'Which is a higher order of organization..or...what?'
Dr. Bert:-Yeah.'

Dr. Alfred:'Yeah, for sure, and this is exactly what we don't know. This is the thing that we don't know from any existing data. It's an old problem, the old, old problem in brain science, the thing that we've been trying to figure out for years and years is how to explain how to...how to define the various levels in the hierarchy of brain organization or a tree of hierarchy of the brain. And this is where you and I are in total agreement that we cannot go on, we have to give up.'
Dr. Bert:-Yeah. I have absolutely no idea whatsoever how to go on as well.'

Dr. Alfred::And the main reason is because we have no idea..how to go on, and this has to be the reason that we have been thinking that we're going to give up as the scientists, and as the philosophers, and as the psychologists have been thinking for years..'
Dr. Bert:'And perhaps that is not right either..'

Dr. Alfred:'Yeah, well, you're the one who's saying that, if you look at the connectivity, and it's not hard-wired at all. In other words, there's nothing in the brain, that's just there. What I'm asking though is that in principle, how do you define order of representation. What is the defining difference between, say a lower-order, and a higher-order?'

Dr. Bert:- Well, that area, you refer to, as being above the eye, which is, of course, above the brain is the primary representation, but this is a higher, which in other words, it's called the higher-order because it's higher than the first order, which is the visual cortex.'
Dr. Bert:\'We all agree that the lower order is the eye area, the higher order, or higher levels of the brain is higher representation, but that difference is that there..'
Dr. Alfred:'Is representation what you're proposing to define as order of representation?'
Dr. Bert:'Well, as far as I know the question was...'
Dr. Bert:'?You don't know much about this. You're here because you know about the human brain, right? And your question is a question that, it's a...'

Dr. Alfred:'I think it may be a good example of your question because what you're asking is that it's not a simple one. It's not so easy to say, 'I'm a scientist. I'm searching for answers in this kind of high order area'. My question is that you're looking, or you want to give an answer, or an approach to these problems. I mean, you're giving an answer to the problems just like the, if you have a, if you got the Nobel prize in your book, or if, if you have some papers in a specific journal then, of course, you are looking very hard, of course, maybe, just like the, just like the rest of us. But what do you mean by the higher order cortex?'

Dr. Alfred:'Yes, but the big concept is that these are important regions where the various visual modules and various other specializations converge, but with such large variability between them, that in principle they can generate a great number of different configurations, which the brain, the organism can sort out and then extract the one that is relevant to the specific function or behavior.'

Dr. Alfred: 'Which is precisely what happens in the limbic system (laughter) and is what is called the preconfigured brain. I just like the term preconfigured brain because it conveys the idea that it is sorta given, not a piece of brain, but that brains are actually preconfigured to do something.'

Dr. Bert:'A little bit further up, there is a frontal associational area, which is a sort of a general associational area, and this is an area that receives information from many sources, and in particular the sources are the subcortical neurotransmitters, and the subcortically delivered information brings about an inhibition of the associational area.'

Dr. Bert: 'Exactly. There are many configurations, but there is such a large variability between them that, when in an animal the stimulus is given, a specific type of association, then it can pick out one of them and say which one is the relevant association, which one responds, and it responds because it already has a special type of information.'

Dr. Alfred:'Exactly. So, now, whether or not I would agree with the fact that a frontal associational zone, which has this highly variable connectivity, is also a visual zone is not a simple question. In fact, I have never seen a picture of one. It's probably there, but there is something more fundamental in the brain because of the way in which the information is processed (laughter). Now, there is also a prefrontal cortical area which is important for emotions, and which communicates with other areas. This is an important cortical module that's preconfigured, in the sense that when in an animal it receives a specific type of information about a particular stimulus, then it can respond with a characteristic emotion, which is a response to something that is called a fear response.'

Dr. Bert:'Exactly. Exactly. In fact, when an animal is trained in this task for a long time, then it can reliably produce fear responses, which in turn, the animal can pick out of its reaction. This is called conditioning, and one can call it preformed brain or preconfigured brain, there is something that seems fundamental about these regions, whether or not is that the same part of the association complex circuit or not.'
Dr. Alfred:'Right, and we know that this area is very, very important, mainly for object identification.'
Dr. Alfred:'The first visual cortex in the...that the cortex of the primate as you know, at least, that the cortex in the human is in this area, right?'

Dr. Bert:\~I've had some students look at this area or at least at the human cadavers where the visual cortex, we know, is relatively, it's not a single area but...there are areas, I guess you'd say regions, within the visual cortex, right?'

Dr. Alfred:'Yes, and these regions are actually relatively well characterized, much more so than the single area. And these areas are important for...not only for identification of objects and other elements in the world, but also...and by extension, for processing motion.'
Dr. Bert: 'Well, this would imply that the primary areas that are not really active are the associational areas, right?'

Dr. Alfred:  It is true, that the associational areas are not that active. You would want to get to the primary motor cortex because of their high activity, not the associational areas. But they are...these are associational areas, because they are areas that, to a large extent, receive inputs from other associational regions.'
Dr. Bert:'From other associational regions, right?'
Dr. Alfred:'We know?'
Dr. Bert:#...but you know, the old concept of the associational areas?'
Dr. Alfred:-...in one context the associational areas. But your term is the visual cortex even though you're talking about higher order cortex.'
Dr. Alfred: #'s expression changed to amused.'
Dr. Alfred:#'s...yeah, that's how we have to define it. It's called semantic area, but you know...'
Dr. Alfred:'What's that mean?'
Dr. Bert:: And, as far as we know, that's, uh, what everybody agrees...'
Dr. Alfred: 'So, you  would be  calling it a syntactical or semantic or  higher-order-?cortex in that case.'

Dr. Alfred:'Well, it's interesting because...we know that in the cat, we can find numerous cortical areas that have their highest density in one structure, such as the olfactory bulb, which is relatively local but then we can find other areas that are much more distant from the olfactory groove, such as layers 2B and 3B, which is the higher frontal associational area.'
Dr. Bert: 'In the mouse how do you do that?'

Dr. Alfred:'It's not known. In the mouse we can work either with the in vivo slice preparation, which is the most beautiful tool in neuroscience, where we can take the piece that we wanted to work on and we cut it in 40 μm slices under the microscope. We have learned how to prepare the slices without touching the tissue, because the goal is to have a smooth cortex surface, which is essential if there are to be any neurons with a high density of ion channels or synapses on them. And every now and then we get something that looks like that. In the last paper I published in 2011 we were able to show that the higher parietal (which in the cat gets subdivided into Bregma area, which is the frontal associational area) cortex, which is rather distant from the olefactory groove area, indeed has its highest number of ion channels in layer 5B, not in layer 5W – which is the associational area. But when...'
Dr. Bert:'What about the other areas?'

Dr. Alfred:'That is difficult. Perhaps the only area that is easy to find is area 11 – the prefrontal area. The interesting question is what kind of inputs are there in that area for its highest density neurons? And we haven't had any luck at this moment, but we may be able to do that in the human prefrontal area, to cut the slices and find out for sure with the highest probability of the cell bodies, you know, that are more local. And...I have my thoughts on the wiring plan that one needs, what is needed, what could possibly do the job. But there is no point to go there until we know...we know what the inputs are and so forth and have the advantage of being able to work with a...'
Dr. Bert:'Well, you know, the more I think about this the more I'm afraid that you're right.'
Dr. Alfred: 'Well, I think there's no reason...I mean, there's a reason to believe that what we see in the visual cortex, what we see on your scalp is what the...'
Dr, Bert:'Oh, of course, that's what you're saying.'

Dr. Alfred:'I just don't know what is the right level to cut. It's really hard to work at this moment in that level of thinking about the function of a network slice, with the idea that there's a goal. The goal is not to have a structure that matches up with our thinking from the outside in world view but the structure that fits the problem. And to then go on and identify the mechanisms by which this structure supports function. And you're right, you're completely right, to ask you the question. And the question is not the wiring that is, it's...what is the best wiring for the job in the highest probability place. And the right answer is in the lowest probability place. And that's...that's the place where we will go. And what we'll end up...by the time we are, we will learn about the mechanisms that support function.'
Dr. Bert:'Yeah.'

Dr. Alfred:'Now we have the same question to ask in the mouse, now if we have very many cortical areas we don't know what we do. And we also don't know how they interact. The best guess is that they perform a series of computations on data presented separately to each of them but that's not sure, of course.'
Dr. Alfred:-'No.'

Dr. Bert:'It's too much work to figure it out, I see, because first of all you cannot tell whether the...a particular structure has a very specific operation. For instance, a structure that produces a particular output, such as a vision pattern or a spatial pattern, right?'
Dr. Alfred:"Exactly.'

Dr. Bert:"So if it has a very specific function, that is, you have to go through an enormous amount of experimentation, so to put, so say, I have a piece of computer paper in the middle of my lab or...in the computer where I have a lot of experimental animals, then there is no reason for all of my animals to go to the same part of that computer paper, right?'
Dr. Alfred:'Yes.'

Dr. Bert:'Well the main problem with the association areas is that nobody knows what they really do. They don't do anything. They're just between the lateral olfactory tract and medial olfactory tract, but when you examine them...a little bit more closely perhaps they do do something.'
Dr. Bert:'So what would you say is the primary purpose or the primary function of this or those areas?'
Dr. Alfred:'Why not?'

Dr. Bert:''Right. In primates navigation is more of a spatial problem, which we refer to as path integration. But many mammals, like your cat, for example, can also navigate by keeping track of the elapsed time.'

Dr. Alfred:'Now, those are some very similar goals. I mean, it does seem to be the same type of problem: the idea that there would be a place field in the cortex and a time field in the hippocampus of the same neurons with the same boundaries, which I call place cells and time cells. So how does the brain distinguish between these two?'
Dr. Bert:'Good question.'

Dr. Alfred:'How would it distinguish between these two? In animals that can generate their own electrical activity, for example, bees in their hive, how would the brain identify time cells? Does that require special cells that track time only, which would in effect be special place cells? But if that was the case, what would distinguish them from place cells?'

Dr. Alfred:':Now, I can only think about one other thing that would be one thing, that there is a special signal that is not one of the physical qualities that distinguishes them from other things because not every signal or every physical property in the brain is a candidate for a place or a time cell.'

Dr. Bert:#now would you say that the special cell that tracks time is the same cell that tracks space?'
Dr. Alfred:'Yes, and that's because neurons have two sides, two aspects.'
Dr. Bert:'So how would you say that you've distinguished between those two sides? You mentioned that there is a signal, special signal?'
Dr. Bert:'That's a fair point.'
Dr. Alfred:'But that's still a path integration, right?'
Dr. Bert:'Certainly, I'm in a park, and where were you when you got a little chocolate? But what if there is no park. Where can a cat, or a mouse, or a rat navigate?'
Dr. Alfred:'No idea.'
Dr. Alfred:'No idea whatsoever?'

Dr. Bert:'I'm really sure that it comes down to the fact that the most important thing is, that these are the parts where the associations of the hippocampus are made. And I think we are going to have to call them that.'
